Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Foundations of Network Design: Real-World Networks, Special Topologies, and Game Theory

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Internet has undergone tremendous growth recently, fueled by the emergence of user-generated video, TV- and movie-on-demand services, peer-to-peer file sharing, social networking, and rapid proliferation of smart phones. These new application mixes and the resulting characteristics of network traffic have raised numerous research challenges for practitioners working on various aspects of networks including construction, routing, and staged deployment. As a result, "network design" or more generally "networking," with its many variants, is one of the most active research areas in computer science.

Theoretical modeling of networks plays a vital role in understanding computer and communication networks. Examples of such theoretical models that will be addressed further in this project are cost and efficiency optimizations with applications in Fiber Optic Networks, Content Distribution Networks (CDNs), Virtual Private Networks (VPNs), Cellular Networks, and Social Networks. The Principal Investigator will invent and use a variety of techniques in approximation and randomized algorithms, fixed parameter algorithms, algorithmic game theory, and his own Bidimensionality theory, to optimize cost and performance of these strategic networks.

As a broader impact, the PI seeks to leverage his network of collaborators to apply these theoretical developments to the design of practical algorithms and mechanisms, to deploy them in real-world settings, and to perform experiments to characterize and explain their behavior and performance. The PI believes that variations of the algorithms designed in this project will be used in real networks, enabling faster networks and cheaper Internet access in practice. This is an especially important goal since the Internet in the U.S. is currently not as fast or cheap as in several other developed or even developing countries.

The wealth of attractive open problems in foundations of network design provide, at one extreme, challenging research topics, and at the other extreme, intuitive and accessible problems to inspire students to enter research in computer science, mathematics, and economics. The educational thrust of this project is to actively engage undergraduate and graduate students in study of and research into network design foundations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is about specific real-world network design problems. The Internet has undergone tremendous growth recently, fueled by the emergence of user-generated video,TV- and movie-on-demand services, peer-to peer file sharing, social networking, and rapid proliferation of smart phones.In particular, new application mixes and the resultingcharacteristics of network traffic have raised numerous researchchallenges. 

Intellectual Merit. In this project, the mainfocus is cost and efficiency optimization with applications in FiberOptic Networks, Content Distribution Networks (CDNs), VirtualPrivate Networks (VPNs), Cellular Networks, and Social Networks. In addition, the project considers the use of game theory and mechanism design to analyze equilibrium states and incentive-aware networks, and more generally, the recent strong relation between network design and game theory.The funds from this project have supported partially the work of thePI, as well as his 16 Ph.D. students (9 graduated already), 2 Master students (with thesis), 5 Post-docs and one long-term Ph.D. student visitors. The PI and his groupmembers were very successful (e.g., our group has four papers that will appear in the upcoming SODA'18) by publishing at least 55papers on the topics of this project (including 18 journal papersand 37 conference papers). You may see the reports for this year and the past year for the list of papers.

Broader Impacts. The PI co-organizedworkshops on bidimensionality at FOCS and Dagstuhl both in 2013, andthe 2011 Workshop on Approximation Techniques at PrincetonUniversity and will co-organize the 9th Flexible Network DesignWorkshop at UMD in the summer of 2018. The PI has also been the mainorganizer of Capital Area Theory Seminar (CATS) at UMD since 2010. Talks and travels of well-known speakers on topics of this project are supported in part by this grant (as mentioned on the website).In recognition of the PI's work, he has received several awardsduring the period of this project in particular European Associationfor Theoretical Computer Science (EATCS) Nerode Prize, 2015 (for his Bidimensionality theory), the University of Maryland Graduate Faculty Mentor of the YearAward, 2015, and ONR Young Investigator Award, 2011. The PI wasChair of Program Committee for SPAA'17 as well (in addition toserving in numerous other conference PCs as well as editorial boardsof journals). The PI has been the coach of the University ofMaryland ACM-ICPC Programming Contest Team (involving mainlyundergrads) in the past seven years, during which the UMD teamadvanced to the finals in \emph{five} years (for which the PIreceived ACM International Collegiate Programming Contest (ICPC)Coach Award, 2017). The PI has also co-developed the University ofMaryland High School Programming competition since 2011 which promotes mathematics and computer science to high-school students both locally and globally through the public website at  http://www.cs.umd.edu/Outreach/hsContest.shtml. Several of the PI's Ph.D. students received prestigious awards (such as  Simons Award for in TCS, Google US/Canada PhD Fellowship(twice}), Ann G. Wylie Dissertation Fellowship, and UMD BestDoctoral Dissertation Awards and prestigious positions (in placessuch as Weizmann, Harvard, and Stanford) in the past.
